results.title: 100,000 children
results.brief_description: A survey of the education system in Toronto in 1960 from kindergarten to adult classes, including commercial courses, technical schools and the administration by a Board of Representatives.

results.title: 100% Parlants et Chantants (1930-1933) Pt. 02
results.brief_description:
Part 2 of a 13 part series on the history of French cinema. By 1930 it becomes clear that the ‘talkies’ are here to stay and all eyes are turned to the USA. American (RCA, Western Electric) and German (TobisKlangFilm) sound systems are quickly adopted, as well as the short-lived routine of filming several language versions of the same film with different sets of actors. Paramount sets up a studio in Joinville, other studios are buit in Epinay, Boulogne-Billancourt as well as in the South of France (Nice/La Victorine). The production level re-establishes itself around 100 to 120 films per year. Germany’s ‘The Blue Angel’ is the first sub-titled film released in Paris. With this film, talkies become all singing and dancing. The advent of the sound era is also a turning point for many careers. Many film actors must accept that their voice is unsuitable for the new medium, while many stage actors discover that their voice training can open the door to a new career. This is the case for Gaby Morlay and especially for Raimu, whose tonitruant voice can win over microphones that are neither sensitive nor directional. Among the stand-out films of this era are Gremillon’s ‘La petite Lise’ (1929), Rene Clair’s ‘Le Million’ (X000265) and ‘A nous la liberte’ (X000158). [*=held in our collection]

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Casard.
Interviewees include: Rene Clair, Pierre Braunberger, Marcel L’Herbier, Yves Allegret, Henri-George Clouzot.

results.title: 100 years: the Australian story (A)
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Sue Spencer and Deborah Masters
results.brief_description: A documentary of Australia, one of the world’s oldest democracies, this extensive and thorough series traces Australian political history. Themes of empire, independence, multiculturalism and indigenous Australia make up this enlightening series. Politicians, activists, experts and everyday Australians contributed to this powerful, educational documentary.

results.title: 100 years of Olympic glory
results.brief_description: Moving tales of courage and persistence, disappointment and victory bring vividly to life the remarkable athletes and amazing feats which have made the modern Olympics a monumental international event. Discover which seven year old boy became the youngest ever Gold Medal winner, what medal a Japanese gymnast won after breaking his knee in the middle of an event and who is called “the fastest human alive.”

results.title: 100 years of Australian football
results.creator_credit: Visual Entertainment Group, Australian Football League, Seven Network Limited (Australia), Neil Kearney and David Barham
results.brief_description: For lovers of the great game of Australian Rules Football, this documentary highlights the game’s magnificent 100 year history. Using archival footage and interviews, the legends of the game including the great Jack Dyer and Mr. Football himself, Ted Whitten are featured together with many past and present heroes.

results.title: 100 watts 120 volts
results.brief_description: Accompanied by the Bach “Brandonburg Concerto” played by the Munich Bach Orchestra, and two very short segments of musique concrete, this film in great detail shows the fully automated manufacture of light bulbs. Produced for Fred A. Niles Communications.

results.title: 100 Pages
results.brief_description: ‘100 Pages’ is a project based upon the theme of North Sydney Girls High School’s Centenary. This project used the School’s identity and history as inspiration for artmaking. Through the artmaking, students are celebrating the school’s identity in the present and past community; isolating individual events, subjects and objects as inspiration. The title of the unit, ‘100 Pages’, comes from the initial idea of 100 animations, for 100 years of history. This project has been developed for the Stage 5 elective, Year 10 Photography and Digital Media class (PDM), which comprises 12 students from North Sydney Girls High School.

results.title: 10 Things I hate about you = Ten Things I hate about you
results.creator_credit: Touchstone Pictures, Andrew Lazar and Gil Junger
results.brief_description: 10 things I hate about you continues the current trend of modernizing William Shakespeare’s back catalogue, which has produced inspired rethinks like Baz Luhrmann’s vibrant disco take on “Romeo and Juliet”, Julie Taymor’s surreal interpretation of “Titus”, Michael Almereyda’s hi-tech “Hamlet” (featuring Julia Stiles) and the American high school setting of “Othello” called “O” (again featuring Julia Stiles). Not surprising then that Julia Stiles stars in this latest twist on Shakespeare’s classic opposites-attract tale, “The Taming of the shrew”. “10 things I hate about you” sticks to the original story quite closely, mostly foregoing the flowery Elizabethan dialogue for a more appropriate teen slang. Otherwise the story set up is the same, the sweet natured Bianca (Larisa Oleynik) is in love with Cameron (Joseph Gorden-Levitt) but is forbidden to date by her paranoid father unless she finds her older sister a boyfriend. Unfortunately her sister Kate (Julia Stiles) is an ill-tempered shrew whose manner towards men is hostile to say the least. Enter mysterious bad boy Patrick (Heath Ledger), who is enlisted by the desperate lovers to win over the impenetrable Kate. Cast includes Larry Miller, Andrew Keegan, David Krumholtz and Susan May Pratt.

results.title: 10 Easy ways to lose your job
results.creator_credit: Reelizations, Donna Boundy and Tom Colello
results.brief_description: Short vignettes illustrate the most common mistakes young people make when they are new to the workforce. These include: calling into work sick at the last minute, chronic lateness, not following instructions and less devious forms of stealing such as taking goods and services from the store or office. There is also an emphasis on attitude and how this affects customer service.
